dc:description:
The relationship between *TMEM126A* and primary mitochondrial disease was evaluated using the ClinGen Clinical Validity Framework as of August 22, 2024. The *TMEM126A* gene encodes an inner mitochondrial membrane protein that is an important complex I assembly factor in ND4-module assembly.	

*TMEM126A* was first reported in relation to autosomal recessive primary mitochondrial disease in 2009 (PMID: 19327736). While various names have been given to the constellation of features seen in those with *TMEM126A*-related disorders, pathogenic variants in this gene cause a primary mitochondrial disease. Therefore, the *TMEM126A* phenotype has been lumped into one disease entity according to the ClinGen Lumping and Splitting Framework.

Evidence supporting this gene-disease relationship includes case-level data and experimental data. This curation included five variants (one nonsense, two missense, one splice site, one frameshift) in 11 probands from seven publications (PMIDs: 19327736, 20405026, 22815638, 30961538, 31119195, 32855858, 36071901). Optic atrophy was the most common clinical feature in affected individuals. Additional clinical features noted include hearing loss, migraines, hypertrophic cardiomyopathy, myoclonic jerks, and brisk reflexes. 

The mechanism of disease is loss of function. This gene-disease association is also supported by the known biochemical function of *TMEM126A* in complex I assembly, functional alteration in non-patient cells, and rescue studies (PMIDs: 33882309, 33879611). 

In summary, there is definitive evidence to support the relationship between *TMEM126A* and primary mitochondrial disease. This relationship has been repeatedly demonstrated in both the research and clinical diagnostic settings and has been upheld over time. This classification was approved by the NICHD/NINDS U24 ClinGen Mitochondrial Disease Gene Curation Expert Panel on August 22, 2024 (SOP Version 10).

evidence.dc:description:
Proteome of KO cells, T126AKO (generated knockout cell lines using genome editing), were assessed by unbiased stable isotope labeling by/with amino acids in cell culture (SILAC) 
Complex I subunits were clearly reduced in mitochondria relative to the controls
A topographical proteomic heatmap was fitted onto the molecular structure of human complex I; subunits belonging to distinct assembly modules of complex I—N-, Q-, ND2-, and ND4-modules—were significantly reduced relative to control mitochondria. 
Complex I assembly in KO cells
Reduction in supercomplex (~50% controls) and in complex I holoenzyme (30% controls; done by immunoblotting for the complex I subunit NDUFB8 with quantification)
A faster-migrating species at ∼440 kDa following digitonin solubilization and ∼400 kDa following Triton X-100 solubilization was also apparent (given that the NDUFB8 subunit is located at the distal end of the complex I membrane arm, this subcomplex may represent an accumulation or breakdown product of this region in the absence of proper complex I assembly)
In-gel NADH dehydrogenase activity showed that the residual complex I observed in T126AKO cells was still active. Besides the complex I supercomplexes, OXPHOS complexes III, IV, or V were not changed in T126AKO mitochondria.
Complemented KO cells with a construct expressing TMEM126A with a C-terminal Flag epitope tag (TMEM126AFlag), demonstrated rescue of the complex I assembly defect.
Performed affinity-enrichment (AE) and label-free quantitative (LFQ) mass spectrometry analysis to determine TMEM126A-interacting partners. 
TMEM126AFlag was able to enrich ND4 and all accessory subunits of the ND4-module (NDUFB1, NDUFB4, NDUFB5, NDUFB10, and NDUFB11) as well some subunits of the Q- (NDUFS2), ND1- (NDUFA8, NDUFA13, and NDUFA3), ND2- (NDUFA10), and ND5- (NDUFB6, NDUFB8, and NDUFB9) modules; also enriched a number of complex I assembly factors including the MCIA complex factors ECSIT and ACAD9, the ND1-module assembly factor TIMMDC1, plus the Q-module assembly factors NDUFAF3 and NDUFAF4. TMEM70, an assembly factor recently implicated in the assembly of the complex I ND4-module was also enriched.

evidence.rdfs:label: Formosa - Rescue

evidence.dc:description:
TMEM126A associates with the newly synthesized mitochondrial DNA (mtDNA)-encoded ND4 subunit of complex I. 
Performed pulse labeling of mtDNA-encoded proteins in cells using [35S]-Methionine in the presence of anisomycin (to block cytosolic translation) for 2 h, before removal of the radiolabel and anisomycin for up to 24 h to allow for maturation of the subunits and their assembly into the OXPHOS complexes 
A strong but transient enrichment of TMEM126AFlag with mtDNA-encoded complex I subunit ND4 was observed
The ND4 subunit was not clearly identified in “total” samples, indicating that the enrichment of this protein by TMEM126AFlag was highly efficient. 
The relatively minor association between TMEM126AFlag with ND1 and ND2 is also consistent with the proteomic analysis and suggests that TMEM126A is involved in assembly of the ND4-module even during integration with the other assembly modules. As expected for an AF, the interaction between TMEM126A and the ND4-module is transient since it is not part of the final assembled complex I.

TMEM126A associates with the newly synthesized mitochondrial DNA (mtDNA)-encoded ND4 subunit of complex I. 
Performed pulse labeling of mtDNA-encoded proteins in cells using [35S]-Methionine in the presence of anisomycin (to block cytosolic translation) for 2 h, before removal of the radiolabel and anisomycin for up to 24 h to allow for maturation of the subunits and their assembly into the OXPHOS complexes

The ND4 subunit was not clearly identified in “total” samples, indicating that the enrichment of this protein by TMEM126AFlag was highly efficient. 
The relatively minor association between TMEM126AFlag with ND1 and ND2 is also consistent with the proteomic analysis and suggests that TMEM126A is involved in assembly of the ND4-module even during integration with the other assembly modules. As expected for an AF, the interaction between TMEM126A and the ND4-module is transient since it is not part of the final assembled complex I.
evidence.rdfs:label: Formosa - Functional alteration (non-patient cells)

evidence.dc:description:
In a 143b cell line, authors analyzed proteins upregulated with NDUFS3 repression and TMEM126A protein was preferentially enriched. Then, they looked at CI assembly and function HAP1 cells in which TMEM126A was knocked out (CRISPR-Cas9). Lack of TMEM126A was associated with:
A reduction of the steady-state levels of several subunits of CI belonging to different modules (amounts of CIII and CIV subunits were not affected)
Strongly reduced rotenone-sensitive CI activity (CII, CIII, CIV, or CS activity were comparable to those of controls)
Severe defect in the amount of active CI-containing SCs and isolated CI (suggesting that TMEM126A is necessary for CI assembly or stability)
No effect on basal respiration, but a significant reduction in the maximal respiratory capacity was found 
No effect on ATP synthesis rates driven by CI and CII substrates, indicating the amount of CI able to assemble in the absence of TMEM126A is sufficient to sustain mitochondrial respiration and the generation of membrane potential under basal conditions, but not when the respiratory chain activity is forced to the maximum by uncoupling. 
KO cells were not able to survive under metabolic stress conditions

Severe defect in the amount of active CI-containing SCs and isolated CI (suggesting that TMEM126A is necessary for CI assembly or stability)
No effect on basal respiration, but a significant reduction in the maximal respiratory capacity was found 
No effect on ATP synthesis rates driven by CI and CII substrates, indicating the amount of CI able to assemble in the absence of TMEM126A is sufficient to sustain mitochondrial respiration and the generation of membrane potential under basal conditions, but not when the respiratory chain activity is forced to the maximum by uncoupling. 
KO cells were not able to survive under metabolic stress conditions
evidence.rdfs:label: D'Angelo - Functional alteration (non-patient cells)
Kloth - Family A
evidence.phenotypeFreeText: This is a 24-year-old Turkish woman with decreased vision from childhood but not diagnosed with optic atrophy until age 14 years.

evidence.rdfs:label: Hanein - Family 3
evidence.phenotypeFreeText: This proband is from a Moroccan family (consanguineous). There are two siblings with optic atrophy (III-2, III-3).

evidence.rdfs:label: La Morgia - Case
evidence.phenotypeFreeText: This is a girl with bilateral optic atrophy noted at age 4 years and migraines since age 14 years. She also had myoclonic jerks and brisk reflexes on exam and bilateral hearing loss. She had normal brain MRI and increased lactate after exercise.

evidence.rdfs:label: Meyer - Family
evidence.phenotypeFreeText:
This proband is from a consanguineous Algerian family. There are two affected individuals who had poor vision from birth and complained of progressive visual loss over time. Fundus examination revealed bilateral temporal optic nerve pallor in both patients with otherwise normal retinal findings
Audiological investigation in both siblings revealed abnormalities falling within the auditory neuropathy/dysynchrony spectrum.

evidence.rdfs:label: Hanein - Family 4
evidence.phenotypeFreeText: This proband is from a Moroccan family. There are two siblings with optic atrophy (III-2, III-3).

evidence.rdfs:label: Kloth - Family C
evidence.phenotypeFreeText: This family has two siblings with childhood onset optic atrophy.

evidence.rdfs:label: Hanein - Family 2
evidence.phenotypeFreeText: This proband is from a Tunisian family (consanguineous) with two siblings with optic atrophy (II-1, II-2) and their fourth cousin once removed (V-1) with optic atrophy. Patient V1 had a normal brain MRI but moderate hypertrophic cardiomyopathy.

evidence.rdfs:label: Li - F98
evidence.phenotypeFreeText: This proband and the brother have optic atrophy.

evidence.rdfs:label: Desir - Case
evidence.phenotypeFreeText: This proband is from a consanguienous Moroccan family with optic atrophy. There are three affected siblings.

evidence.rdfs:label: Hanein - Family 1
evidence.phenotypeFreeText: This proband is from a consanguineous (parents first cousins) Algerian family with optic atrophy. There are 5 siblings with optic atrophy (III-5, III-6, III-8, III-9, III-11) and 6 siblings unaffected (III-1, III-2, III-3, III-4, III-7, III-10). The phenotype in proband and affected siblings was early-onset severe bilateral deficiency in visual acuity (VA), optic disc pallor, and central scotoma (onset between 4 and 6 years; VA counting fingers to 20/200. Visual field was strictly normal in all but the oldest patient, who lost it between the age of 30 and 37. There was mild hearing loss was noted in III-6.

evidence.rdfs:label: Seo - Pt 16
evidence.phenotypeFreeText: This person had early childhood onset optic atrophy (diffuse optic atrophy was observed on fundus exam, there was also a profound loss of peripapillary retinal nerve fiber layer on OCT).
